input:
M: Polly, Ms. Kelly has agreed to come and give a talk about international relations next week. When do you think we can fit her lecture in? ,F: That's Great, Nick. What about Friday afternoon then? ,M: I'm afraid some students are planning to go on a trip. Maybe we can have it on Wednesday afternoon. ,F: No, that's not possible, either. Most students are having group activities for their research projects. Well, I have an idea. I have a class on Tuesday afternoon and probably Ms. Kelly can use my time.
(A) M: Sure. Ms. Kelly can give the lecture on Friday. (B) M: Just a minute! I do not quite follow what you are saying, would you mind repeating that? (C) M: Sure. Ms. Kelly can give the lecture on Wednesday. (D) M: Sure. Ms. Kelly can give the lecture on Tuesday.

M: So what kind of job did you find for this summer? ,F: I'm working for a marketing company. I'm doing telephone marketing. ,M: Oh, so you are one of those people who drive me crazy by calling me up in trying to persuade me to buy something that I have no need for. Do you like it?
(A) F: No, I don't. My job is write texts for a company. (B) F: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again? (C) F: Yes, I do. So I sell things over the telephone. (D) F: No, I don't. I was sell things over the telephone, but now I don't.

M: Mom, can I go out to play? ,F: Well, did you get your Saturday's work done? ,M: Um, do I have to, mom? ,F: You know the rules. No playing until the work is done. ,M: So what is my work? ,F: Well, first, you have to clean the carpet of the family room and the hall and be sure to dust everything. Oh, and don't forget to wipe the walls. ,M: OK. ,F: And after that, sweep and mop the kitchen floor and be sure to polish the table in the living room. ,M: OK, OK.
(A) F: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please? (B) F: You should polish the table in that bedroom . (C) F: Don't forget to polish the table in the living room. (D) F: Don't forget to polish the floor in the living room.

M: Hasn't it been hard for you without your sister and brother, mom? ,F: Yes, Sam, of course. We haven't seen each other for a long time. ,M: Mom, I have a surprise for you. I'll go on a business trip to Russia. I want you to come with me. You can meet them finally.
(A) F: Really? You don't want me to come with you and you go to Russia for my wishes? (B) F: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (C) F: Really? You mean you will go to Russia for business? Oh, that's a great surprise! (D) F: You will go to Russia for business? Don't worry, it hasn't been hard for me without my sister and mom.

F: What would you say are your strengths? Based on your resume you seem to have a lot of work experience. ,M: I work well both individually and in groups. ,F: What would you say might be a weakness in your work? ,M: Uhm, wow, tough question! Well, maybe I can be a little nervous at first, and not confident in my work. But that's just in the beginning. ,F: That happens to every one. Our training will help you with that. ,M: That sounds great! I am very interested in learning everything I can about the job. ,F: Tell me, where do you see yourself 5 years from now?
(A) M: I didn’t hear you. Please could you tell me again? (B) M: You mean what I will have accomplished in a few years. (C) M: I doubt whether I am suitable for the company because I don't work well work in groups. (D) M: You mean you want to know what I will have accomplished in a few years since I don't work well individually.

F: David, look, what a beautiful red dress and the blue one looks beautiful, too. ,M: Frankly, I like this white dress the best. ,F: Then I'll take this one. ,M: Ok, now, Lisa, you put on the dress in the fitting room. While I go and pay the money. We've got to hurry or we'll be late for Jenny's party.
(A) F: Since you like this red dress best, I'll take it. (B) F: Excuse me, could you repeat the question? (C) F: Since you like this blue dress best, I'll take it. (D) F: Although you like this red dress best, I'll take the white one.

M: Do you remember that Jane went to Hollywood a few months ago? ,F: Yes and she never came back. ,M: Well, she met a famous director and now they're getting married in a few weeks. ,F: Wow, that happens only once in a lifetime.
(A) M: I agree with you that Jane is really lucky to marry a famous director. (B) M: Well, I also know that unknown director. (C) M: Hollywood welcomes everyone who wants to go, and maybe you can meet a famous director there as Amy did. (D) M: I’m sorry, I didn’t understand. Could you repeat a little louder, please?

F: Good Morning, Room Service. May I help you? ,M: Yes, I'd like to have supper in my room, please. ,F: OK, Sir. We offer different types of cuisine, Chinese, American, French and Italian, which one would you prefer? ,M: The first, please. What would I have for supper then? ,F: Rice, chicken, tomato and egg soup, and some lettuce.
(A) M: Great, these are some of my favorite types of French food. (B) M: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again? (C) M: Great, I love having Chinese food as lunch! (D) M: Great, these are some of my favorite types of Chinese food.

M: I want to know why you're sitting with your mouth closed all the evening. What's wrong, honey? ,F: Well, I don't like being a typist. There's no one to talk with and the day goes too slowly.
(A) M: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (B) M: OK, I see. You don't like being a typist. Well , honey, as your huaband, I will support your any decision. (C) M: Oh, now I know why you're sitting with your mouth closed all the morning. Honey, as your huaband, I will support you. (D) M: Yeah, there's no one to talk with and the day goes too fast. But as your boss, I hope you can continue your work.

M: It was very nice of you to invite me. ,F: I'm very glad you could come, Doctor Wong. What would you like? ,M: This is my first time at a Chinese restaurant. Could you tell me the different features of Chinese food? ,F: Generally speaking, Beijing food is a bit oily. Shanghai food is rather light and Hunan dishes are very spicy.
(A) M: Haha, I've been here before, so I know that Beijing meals have a light taste. (B) M: You must like the light taste of Shanghai food, so I invite you here to try it. (C) M: Just a minute! I do not quite follow what you are saying, would you mind repeating that? (D) M: Oh, yes. Hunan meals have a light taste and Shanghai food is very spicy.

M: Anna just email to say that the managers meeting is put off till next Monday. Will you have everything ready by then, Sabrina? Hey Sabrina, what's wrong? ,F: I'm so worried. I haven't heard from my sister for 2 weeks. ,M: How often do you call each other? ,F: Normally at least once a week. But she's now a volunteer teacher in a mountain village in Africa. I can only write her. ,M: The Mail can be really slow sometimes. I'm sure you'll hear from her soon.
(A) F: Thank you. I am worried about her because she is teaching in a village in Africa. (B) F: Thank you. I am worried about her because she is touring in Africa. (C) F: Thank you. I just want to know how my sister is teaching in the village in America. (D) F: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please?

M: Where will we go on your vacation? ,F: Well, I speak some French so I decided to go to a country where they speak French. ,M: So, you go to France? ,F: Actually no, and I don't go to Spain this time. I'll spend my whole vacation in Morocco. ,M: I'll take the most interesting trip to China. ,F: China? Not South Korea? I thought you're going to South Korea. ,M: I want to go to China and South Korea, but I don't have enough time. ,F: I don't know you're interested in China. ,M: China is a fascinating country and I got to see most of it. I love Chinese art.
(A) F: Wish you have a pleasant journey to Korea this time! (B) F: Why are you interested in Chinese music instead of arts? (C) F: Wow, it surprises me that you are a fan of Chinese culture. (D) F: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again?

F: Hey, you have so many clocks in your bedroom. Are you crazy or what? ,M: No, I am a heavy sleeper. I want to make sure I can wake up in the morning.
(A) F: I'm surprised that you get up late every day since you are such a light sleeper. (B) F: As a heavy sleeper, no wonder you put so many clocks in your kitchen. (C) F: I am afraid I did not quite catch what you were saying. Please repeat it. (D) F: That's a lot of clocks, seems you really have difficulty waking up.

M: Hi Daisy. ,F: Hi Tom. I hope you are getting on well at college. ,M: I am. I've made lots of friends and I really enjoy my courses. ,F: Great. Me, too. So what do you like most about our college? ,M: I especially like the swimming pool. ,F: Yes, me too. The school gym and the playground are very good. Oh, you didn't tell me what you are studying there. ,M: I'm doing business studies. I hope to get a job in Toronto after graduating since that's where my parents live now.
(A) F: Wow, cool. So you are in Canberra now. (B) F: Wow, cool. So you are in Toronto now. (C) F: Wow, cool. So your father is in Sydney now. (D) F: Excuse me, could you repeat the question?

F: Hello, Sir. Could you spare me a minute? ,M: Sure, Jay. You look upset. What happened? ,F: Well, you know, it's Kevin. He's telling everyone that David and I are in love. But we're not. We're just a study pair. You know, I help him with his English and he helps me with my math. ,M: Oh, I was going to tell you that you have made great progress in math. That explains. Don't worry. I'll talk to Kevin tomorrow.
(A) F: So, you mean you will talk to Kevin the day after tomorrow? Thanks, dad. (B) F: Really? You mean I have made no progress in math? Oh, teacher, I am very sad to hear that. (C) F: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please? (D) F: Really? You will not talk to Kevin tomorrow? Oh, you are my boss and I think you should do it for me.

F: Mike, what did Tim say just now? ,M: He said it'll rain this afternoon. ,F: Really? But it's such a beautiful day.
(A) M: It is sunny now, but it may rain in the afternoon. (B) M: Yes. It is going to rain all day. (C) M: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (D) M: Yes. It is cloudy now and maybe raining in the afternoon.

F: Are you going to camp this summer? ,M: Oh no, I'm too old for that now. I'm going to a hiking trip. What are you going to do? ,F: This year I'm going to be a camp teacher.
(A) M: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (B) M: Sounds great. I am going riding this summer. (C) M: Well, instead of going hiking, I will go camping. (D) M: That's nice. I think I will go hiking this summer.

F: How was Sports Day? Did Greenhouse win the most events? ,M: Well, Greenhouse usually wins but this year they came second. Red House was surprisingly good as well, but Blue House got the highest total of points in the end.
(A) F: Excuse me, could you repeat the question? (B) F: It is really for Red House to win the game. (C) F: Congratulation to Blue House! (D) F: It seems that Blue House wins every year.

F: Which TV channel do you like best? ,M: Sports channel is my favorite. You can't imagine there are so many exciting sports.
(A) F: Let's buy this TV, 30% off. (B) F: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (C) F: I like the news channels so much. Why do you think all TV programs are boring? (D) F: Our school will hold a sports meeting next week.

M: I can't believe there's another biology test. There are so many unfamiliar terms. ,F: At least you weren't taking chemistry like me, so many things to remember. ,M: Well, I hear physics classes, even harder.
(A) F: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please? (B) F: I can't believe that you find biology tests easy. (C) F: Tell me how do you think of biology test? Did you have a high score? (D) F: Lucky that you take physics. Physics tests are simple.

M: Mary, I'm going to London tomorrow. ,F: Oh, yes. Are you going by bus? ,M: It's the best way. There is a fast train but it's too expensive for me.
(A) F: So, you will travel to London by car because there is no fast train? (B) F: OK, I see. You mean there is a fast train and it's too cheap for you, so you will travel to London by train. (C) F: OK, I see. Since it's too expensive for you, you will travel to London by bus the day after tomorrow. (D) F: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again?

M: Excuse me, do you know where the auditorium is? ,F: I'm not sure. I'm looking for it, too, because my friend is waiting for me there. She had literature classes there this morning. I think it's this way. ,M: Do you mind if I walk with you? ,F: Of course not. What class do you have there? ,M: I'm taking the introductory economics class. I hear it's a big class. ,F: Yeah, my roommate took the class last semester and she said there were over 300 people in the lecture hall.
(A) M: Just a minute! I do not quite follow what you are saying, would you mind repeating that? (B) M: You knew that the economics class has a lot of students in the school newspaper, didn't you? (C) M: So you took the economics class last semester, right? What do you think of it? (D) M: Oh, your roommate took the math course last semester. Does she like it?

M: Hey, Sarah. This year I'm going to the rock festival for all three days. ,F: Oh, lucky you, Leo. Are you going with your cousin again? ,M: Not this year. My brother has promised at take me there now. My sister is too busy with her college work. ,F: How will you get there? ,M: We want to drive but dad said no and it's too far from the city for us to cycle there. But there are special buses so we'll use those. ,F: What do you have to take with you? ,M: Just a tent in clothes really. We'll need lots of water but we'll buy that an all our meals there. Hey, come with us.
(A) F: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please? (B) F: Yes, a tent in clothes is useful at the festival. (C) F: So you will take drinks with you to the concert. (D) F: I don't think you have to take food with you.

F: Hello, who's that? ,M: Hello, Mrs Black. I'm David. I'm coming to fix your TV set. ,F: Oh, come in please.
(A) M: I'm here to show you my novel. (B) M: I’m sorry, I didn’t catch that. Would you mind speaking more slowly? (C) M: Where is the TV you want to repair? (D) M: I'm not a repairman.

F: Are you OK? ,M: I think so. I'm just a little frightened. ,F: I should think so that looks like a pretty bad accident. ,M: It was, my guess I'm lucky. ,F: You bet you are. What happened? ,M: Well, I was just driving around the corner back there. And I lost control of the car. I must have hit an ice patch.
(A) F: I didn’t hear you. Please could you tell me again? (B) F: Let's go to the hospital since you hit the patch and got injured badly. (C) F: Why you had the bet with the other car? Luckily, you didn't lost control of the car. (D) F: You hit an ice patch! It could be worse. Fortunately you are not injured.

M: My son's just tried to book some tickets for the Black Key Concert on March twenty-first, but there's a problem with your website. ,F: I'm sorry about that. There are only the most expensive tickets left for that date, I'm afraid. ,M: What about the twentieth? Have you got any for $25? ,F: Sorry, those are all sold out. But there are some on the nineteenth, or there are $35 ones on the twentieth. ,M: Yes, those would be best. The nineteenth is no good because he's got school the next day.
(A) F: Okay, please give me $15 for the football game ticket. (B) F: It' s a good deal to pay $25 for the football game ticket. (C) F: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (D) F: Sir, please give me $35 for the Black Key Concert ticket.

M: It was very nice of you to invite me. ,F: I'm very glad you could come, Doctor Wong. What would you like? ,M: This is my first time at a Chinese restaurant. Could you tell me the different features of Chinese food? ,F: Generally speaking, Beijing food is a bit oily. Shanghai food is rather light and Hunan dishes are very spicy. ,M: Chinese dishes are delicious. They have a very nice color, too.
(A) F: Excuse me, could you repeat the question? (B) F: I love Chinese food. Thank you for inviting me here again, darling. (C) F: How about Hunan meals, Dr. Yang, which is never spicy? I'll pay. (D) F: Haha, indeed. Just try whatever you want to try. The bill is on me.

F: We join our cooks as they are making this week's dish - Turkish Baklava. Glenn is adding chocolate to his. Glenn, tell us how long you've been interested in baking? ,M: My grandmother taught me when I was 5. But I didn't really get interested in Essen till I was 20.
(A) F: I’m sorry, I didn’t understand. Could you repeat a little louder, please? (B) F: It very creative to add chocolate in the baklava. (C) F: It very creative to newly add honey in the baklava. (D) F: It very creative to newly add nuts in the baklava.

F: Did you see today's newspaper? That building over there in center view was just struck by lightning for the fourth time. ,M: I'm not surprised. If the conditions for lightning to strike are right one time, they might be as good another time. ,F: Well, I don't take any chances. If I'm caught in a thunderstorm, I will look for a building or a closed car. Also, I was told that if you're stuck outdoors, the best thing you can do is to keep yourself close to the ground and avoid bodies of water.
(A) M: Well, you are right, stand on the ground is the only way to avoid thunder striking. (B) M: Yes, I agree with you that you should go to a swimming pool when it is thunderstorms. (C) M: Yes, you'd better to find a house to avoid thunder striking when you were caught in a thunderstorm. (D) M: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again?

M: Good afternoon, how may I help you, Madam? ,F: Hello, I reserved a room here. The day before yesterday, are room for 2 from the thirteenth to the fifteenth. ,M: Ok, may I have your name? ,F: Yes, it's Jenny Green. ,M: Just one moment, please. Ah yes, here it is, I'll just print out the details for you to confirm. You are in room 408.
(A) F: One day on the 13th for Jenny Green, yes. Room 308, got it. (B) F: It says a room is reserved for 5 days from the 9th for me, yes. (C) F: I didn’t hear you. Please could you tell me again? (D) F: Let me look, three days from the 13th to 15th. That's correct.

F: Hello, Mister Brown. This is Sarah. I'm afraid I won't be able to see you this afternoon. ,M: What's up? ,F: I don't feel alright. I'm on my way to the hospital now.
(A) M: Oh, you should see a doctor now. (B) M: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (C) M: You should see the doctor in the morning and meet me in the afternoon. (D) M: Oh, you should visit your friends first.

M: I'd like some information about opening a savings account. ,F: A savings account? Certainly, what would you like to know? ,M: Could you tell me what the interest rate is? ,F: It's five and a quarter percent.
(A) M: Well, I don't want any information about opening a savings account in this hotel. Please stopping talking about it. (B) M: Really? It's four and a quarter percent? Oh, it's very low in this supermarket. (C) M: Okay, I see. I want some information about closing a savings account in this bank. (D) M: Just a minute! I do not quite follow what you are saying, would you mind repeating that?

M: It's Saturday tomorrow. Do you have any plans? ,F: Busy as usual. I will send Annie to her piano class at 9:00 tomorrow morning and then take Michael to hospital. Besides, I will make a birthday cake for Lynn. Tomorrow is her fifth birthday. ,M: Why isn't John giving a hand? ,F: An international meeting is going to be held in London next week. He is leaving tomorrow and will be back in 2 weeks.
(A) M: I am really sorry, I did not catch that. Would you slow down, please? (B) M: Oh, John has a local meeting in London. He'll miss Annies' birthday tomorrow. (C) M: So John will attend a piano concert next week, but he'll leave after tomorrow. (D) M: John is leaving for an international meeting in London? He is also very busy.

M: Would you like to go to the cinema with me tonight? ,F: I'd love to, but I have to pay a visit to my parents, maybe we can go tomorrow.
(A) M: What do you think if I visit your parents with you tonight? (B) M: Sure. You can visit your parents tonight and we can play basketball tomorrow. (C) M: I’m sorry, I didn’t understand. Could you repeat a little louder, please? (D) M: Maybe we can have dinner before we go to the class together.

M: Can you arrange for a candle light dinner for tomorrow? I have been impressed with your restaurant since I had a meeting last time here. ,F: Certainly, sir. When should we arrange? ,M: Is it possible at 7:30 PM? ,F: Surely. ,M: Oh, no, no. My wife will take part in her friend's birthday party tomorrow afternoon. So please put it off half an hour later.
(A) F: I am afraid I did not quite catch what you were saying. Please repeat it. (B) F: OK. The candle light dinner will begin at 8:00 pm. (C) F: Sure. The candle light dinner will start at 8:00 pm today. (D) F: OK. We will arrange the dinner at 8:30 pm tomorrow.

M: Excuse me, would you mind if I use your stapler? ,F: Help yourself. It's on the desk over there. Oh, I'm sorry, it has been lent out.
(A) M: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again? (B) M: I have take the stapler away. (C) M: You owned it. (D) M: Somebody else has take away the book.

M: I lost my dog. Can you help me look for him? ,F: Yes, of course. When was the last time you saw him? ,M: I tide him up right here as I went to grab some coffee. When I came back outside, he was gone. ,F: OK, what does he look like? ,M: He's white with black spots He's around 40 pounds and has short hair. His name is Milo and he always comes when he's called.
(A) F: Milo is black with white spots and has long hair, that's not common so don't worry we'll find him. (B) F: I’m sorry, I didn’t catch that. Would you mind speaking more slowly? (C) F: Well, Milo is only 14 pounds and he is black with grey spots, so he will be found easily. (D) F: Alright, I know, a dog with short hair, let's search for him together and we will find him.

M: I'm hungry, do you want to go to the burger shop and get something to eat? ,F: Sure, but I need to stop at the drug store first. I need some vitamins.
(A) M: That's okay. I can wait. Please buy me soft drinks. (B) M: Excuse me, could you repeat the question? (C) M: That's okay. I can wait. Thanks for buying me some breads. I don't eat burgers any more. (D) M: That's okay. I can wait. Thanks for buying me some burgers.

M: Lucy, I heard that you got a part-time job. Is that true? ,F: Yes Jack, I am working as a guide in our cities museum. I explained basic details about pictures, items and the like to the visitors. ,M: That sounds like a hard job. You must have to learn a lot about history. ,F: I do, but that's ok. I like reading about the past, history helps us to know what to do in our present situation. I love the job. ,M: You will learn a lot in this job. ,F: And most importantly, I can get some good work experience.
(A) M: I understand. Guiding in museum is indeed a good work experience for you. (B) M: You don't have to learn history as a cleaner, so you enjoy more spare time. (C) M: I’m sorry, I didn’t understand. Could you repeat a little louder, please? (D) M: Lily, so you love the useful working experience of being a history teacher.

F: Good afternoon, Royal Bank. How may I help you? ,M: Hello. I have an account with your bank and I'd like to have a copy of my bank statement. I tried to reach you this morning but the lines were all busy. Can I request a statement over the phone?
(A) F: Okay, I'll help you to draw some money from Lloyds Bank.. (B) F: Okay, I'll help you to have a copy of your bank statement. (C) F: Okay, I'll help you to open an account of Lloyds Bank. (D) F: I am afraid I did not quite catch what you were saying. Please repeat it.

M: Hello, Catherine. What about your test? ,F: Not too bad. But the travel was that I kept thinking of so many things at once, so I didn't have time to finish the test. ,M: How many questions did you answer? ,F: Oh, I did all nine of them. But I didn't really have time to finish the last one properly.
(A) M: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again? (B) M: Take it easy, you completed nine of the ten questions in the test. (C) M: Oh, you're great,you had done all nine questions in the test. (D) M: Don't worry, though the test had ten questions, you finished eight of them.

M: What are you doing this Saturday, Gene? ,F: Well, first thing in the morning I'm going to take my driving test. ,M: Really? I thought you had a driver's license. ,F: No, I've never needed one. I've always lived in Boston and it's easy to get around on public transportation. But now I'm taking a job in Los Angeles. ,M: Congratulations. ,F: Thanks. But everyone knows that to live in LA you have to drive. So I've been taking lessons and I'm going to take my test tomorrow.
(A) M: Good luck! I didn't know you got a new job in San Francisco. (B) M: Good luck! When will you on board your new job? (C) M: Good luck! Are you going to buy a new car? I can go with you and maybe give you some advice. (D) M: I’m sorry, I didn’t understand. Could you repeat a little louder, please?

F: Good morning, John. Have you finished reading the novel by Dickens borrowed from the library? ,M: No, I caught a cold 2 days ago. I only finish reading half of it. ,F: I'm sorry to hear that. How are you feeling now? ,M: I'm feeling better today.
(A) F: I didn’t hear you. Please could you tell me again? (B) F: It's great that you've finished two-thirds of your reading even though you've caught a cold. (C) F: You've finished reading the novel I bought! Too fast! (D) F: I'm sorry to hear that you caught a cold two days ago.

M: Do you like to go to the zoo on Sunday? ,F: Yes, I like to go to the zoo. But not on Sundays, because it's always so crowded. How about going on a Friday or Saturday?
(A) M: So you don't like going to the zoo on Sundays, do you? (B) M: So you don't like to go to the zoo on Fridays because it's crowded, right? (C) M: So you don't like going to the zoo on Sundays and Saturdays, do you? (D) M: I didn’t hear you. Please could you tell me again?

F: Excuse me, I have seen the camera advertised online for 150 pounds? ,M: Well, we're selling it for 180 pounds. It usually sells for 200 pounds, but we have a special offer now.
(A) F: I’m sorry, I don’t understand. Could you say it again? (B) F: 180 pounds is the original price but I'll buy this camera. (C) F: Great! 180 pounds, right? I'll buy one. (D) F: I'll buy it! I can save 20 pounds as the camera is 200 pounds now.

F: Have you handed in your papers, John? ,M: Sorry, Mrs Smith. I haven't finished them yet. ,F: But you must have handed them in by last Friday. And now it's Monday. ,M: I am terribly sorry. The problem is I wrote it with my computer, but it failed to work. I need some time to get it repaired. I promise I'll give them to you in 2 days.
(A) F: Please remember that you promise to hand in your papers on Monday. You should have handed them in last Monday. (B) F: Bear your promise that you will finish the task on Wednesday in mind. Today is Sunday, you get three days left. (C) F: I am sorry. You spoke so rapidly that I did not catch the meaning of what you said. Could you repeat that? (D) F: Since you have a computer that works well, you should finish your papers and hand them in on Thursday as you promised.

M: Where do you want to go, Madam? ,F: The Hilton Hotel, please? Uh, it's cold, huh? I'm freezing. ,M: Come on, San Francisco's usually cold in winter, you know?
